subject: Add utility code to monitor host state
commitMessage:
Add utility code to monitor host state

For SST (and possibly other PECI users), we need to know when CPU is not
available (to avoid using PECI), and when BIOS is booting (to avoid race
condition on configuring SST).

Subscribes to CurrentHostState to determine S5/S0 state, and also
CoreBiosDone to determine if BIOS is done.

Tested: as part of child change
Ie6eed8ab23bff289e01d6d125402a5509d3a9110

Signed-off-by: Jonathan Doman <jonathan.doman@intel.com>
Change-Id: I6a2ce21193d91a7efe53f7e48bcd57e685c903ff

Change has been successfully merged by Jonathan Doman
I believe that get_if can return a nullptr.
True, and the if() is checking the value which was returned/assigned, so the handler is not called if it's null.

Just curious: why don't you use same resource as dbus-sensors: OperatingSystemState in xyz.openbmc_project.State.OperatingSystem.Status, based on POST_COMPLETE GPIO from PCH (https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/include/Utils.hpp#L100)

The two are pretty close in meaning, but CoreBiosDone is (for some reason) considered more reliable and will be preferred over the GPIO going forward - see https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/x86-power-control/+/40108. Once that x86-power-control change is merged, this code could go back to using OperatingSystemState.
I see now that x86-power-control will not use CoreBiosDone. Still, there is little practical difference for this code, so I'll probably leave it as is unless I have to make another code update.
Went back to OperatingSystemState
not true anymore, remove comment

static
initialize

Can you still read the reply if the service is down?
No, good catch. moved into try block
Does it have to be lambda? Can it be an old fashioned function pointer?

In fact, I have never tested this code with lambdas, since for the current code I'm only using pointers to free functions. But I still wrote this with arbitrary handlers in mind, just to practice with templates and lambdas a bit.
Done
nit: function name a little misleading for me because it also setup the match in addition to initialize hostState
Done - renamed to hostStateSetup
This function should only be called once per service, it might be better to just add the two subscribe calls in the main function.
Added internal static flag to make sure they don't get called multiple times.
Should this be moved into try block also?

Yes, good catch! I had assumed std::variant would be valueless by default, but rather the default constructor creates a variant holding the value-initialized value of the first alternative. The first alternative happens to be PropertyType here, so if the D-Bus call fails, this code will still call the handler().
Done

This comment is wrong, now that I understand lambdas and forward a little better. If the caller passes handler by lvalue&, then we will make a copy of it. If we make one copy, then we could make two and copy into both match callbacks, so the comment is misleading. But the code still works fine as it is, so I'll only fix this comment if I make another change.
Done
Possible race condition - new State received, biosDone has not updated, result in skipping biosInProgress state

biosDone is initialized to false (and powerState to Off), so the hostState should never get "farther" (later boot state) than it really is, unless there's something wrong with the D-Bus services. Can you write out the exact sequence of events you're thinking of?

Here is what I think the normal sequence
1. powerState = off, biosDone = false => Host Off
2. powerState != off, biosDone no change => BiosInProgress
3. powerState no change, biosDone = true => BiosComplete
4. powerState = off, biosDone  no change => Host Off
5. powerState no change, biosDone = false => Host Off
6. powerState != off, biosDone no change => BiosInProgress
7. powerState no change, biosDone = true => BiosComplete

Question is: will #5 always happen and can the order of 5 and 6 can be guaranteed?
OK, I see your point - will think about it. My guess is that the "normal" sequence is guaranteed.

Probably is - at least now. 
But it also seems ok to set biosDone = false, when powerState = off is received.
That should prevent the race and no unwanted side affect I can think of at this moment.
good suggestion! done.
Do you need update time to 2020-2021?
Done
Done

nit: This is marked as utility code can be used generic(though its not case here now but future it may), so these commants makes it specific to PECI here. We can get rid of this as long as we are building utility code for hostState here.
Done
lowerCamelCase
Done
Do you need update time to 2020-2021
Done
Done
Better use coreBiosDone instead of OSState which is what we need here.

Haha, I've already gone back and forth twice! Can you explain why CoreBiosDone is better? I went back to OSStatus because it is a more "generic" interface, and at least with x86-power-control, is controlled by POST_COMPLETE signal. Whereas CoreBiosDone is asserted before POST complete.

We have different stages of BIOS. Power off(S5), Power On(S0 - using PS_PEROK assert), Core bios done(After BIOS complete the DXE phase) and POST complete(After BIOS complete).  Now, Coming to this specific case9CPU info via PECI), which is available after core BIOS done(Dxe exist), no need to wait till end of BIOS.
OK, I will switch back to coreBiosDone.
Done
Use Async method calls

Ok, I switched to async since it was less code to write, but I think it makes for slightly worse behavior. Before, hostState was guaranteed to be initialized after hostStateInit returns whereas now we have to make sure the event loops runs before hostState gets updated. Not a big deal, but I hope we continue to use synchronous d-bus calls where it makes sense.
I am in favor of using sync blocking calls, where the next operation is completely blocked. But in this case, I don't see hard blocking, PECI Loop can wait till power state initialized properly.
Better add these logs to journalctl for run time debug purpose instead of masking under compile time flag.
Done

If the propertyName matches, we can enter for loop and get value using std::get_if. That ways<
 - we can break for loop as we already got propertyName match
 - We can also log error for wrong property type - better debugging.
Done

nit: Any specific reason for split and perform two read() calls instead of making it in single call?
reply.read(intf, changedProps);
Done
I am not clear on this? Its not some, All should use the fully-qualified dbus enum with (xyz.openbmc_project.State.OperatingSystem.Status.OSStatus.<x>). Or did i understood it wrongly?
You are correct about what *should* be done, but x86-power-control doesn't do that. It sets the property to just the last fragment of the enum string ("Inactive" or "Standby"), hence this workaround.
Doesn't matter any more, not using this property
Ok
nit: can you rename it to coreBiosDone, instead of biosDone which may mislead.
You need to change this enum name to dxePhaseComplete ( Now post complete is not correct).
Agree it's inaccurate, will fix if I make another change.
